dc:description:
The *PROM1* gene was first reported in relation to autosomal dominant retinal degeneration in 2008 (PMID: 18654668). The phenotypic spectrum includes the following clinical diagnoses: STGD4 (Stargardt Disease-4) characterized by macular dystrophy, yellow fundus flecks, and dark choroid pattern (PMID: 10420191); autosomal dominant MCDR2 (retinal macular dystophy-2 ) characterized by retinal pigment epithelium atrophy, bull's-eye macular dystrophy, visual impairment, central scotomata, and age-related rod and cone abnormalities (PMID: 12657606); autosomal dominant cone-rod dystrophy characterized by both cone and rod photoreceptor degeneration (PMID: 18654668). Per criteria outlined by the ClinGen Lumping & Splitting Working Group, dominant cases were compared with cases of PROM1-related recessive retinopathy, which includes cone-rod dystrophy 12 and retinitis pigmentosa 41. The recessive disease is more severe with earlier onset, and is associated with null or close to null PROM1 function. The dominant disease is associated with milder phenotypes, and has a late adulthood age onset. It is associated with missense variants and thought to arise via a dominant negative mechanism. Due to the distinct underlying molecular mechanisms of the two disease forms, dominant cases were split from the recessive cases and were collectively curated under PROM1-related dominant retinopathy.

Four suspected disease-causing missense variants were scored as part of this curation, which have been collectively reported in twelve probands in nine publications (PMID: 18654668, PMID: 10205271, PMID: 12657606, PMID: 38072963, PMID: 20393116, PMID: 28840994, PMID: 31576780, PMID: 29416601, PMID: 28095140).  All except three probands harbor the p.Arg373Cys variant. Three large families with distinct disease haplotypes showed strong evidence of co-segregation of the genotype with affected status (PMID: 18654668). The literature included more case-level and co-segregation evidence, but its inclusion in this curation was not necessary to reach the maximum score for genetic evidence.

This gene-disease association is also supported by experimental evidence indicating that degeneration of the photoreceptor layer may be the shared defect underlying PROM1-related disease. *PROM1* is specifically expressed in retinal tissues (PMID: 30239781) and the protein product localizes particularly to the discs at the base of the photoreceptor cell outer segments (PMID: 18654668, PMID: 10587575). This localization is consistent with the known association of PROM1 with membrane protrusions (PMID: 10681530) and its proposed function in cell membrane homeostasis by regulating formation of extracellular vesicles (PMID: 39168849). PROM1 is an integral membrane protein that associates with cholesterol, and mutations in cholesterol binding domains affect membrane homeostasis in cultured mammalian cells. The cadherin family member CDHR1 gene product co-immunoprecipitates with PROM1 (PMID: 18654668), and harbors variants associated with cone-rod dystrophy 15 (PMID: 20805371), retinal macular dystrophy (PMID: 28765526), and retinitis pigmentosa 65 (PMID: 20087419). A transgenic mouse expressing the dominant PROM1 p.Arg373Cys variant showed similar phenotypes observed in human STGD4 and MCDR2 cases; the mutant mouse retina showed disorganized outer segment disc membranes and mislocalized PROM1, supporting the role of PROM1 in membrane organization in photoreceptors.

In summary, *PROM1* is definitively associated with PROM1-related dominant retinopathy. This has been demonstrated in both research and diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time without the emergence of contradictory evidence, leading to a Definitive classification. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Retina Gene Curation Expert Panel on October 3rd, 2024 (SOP Version 10).

evidence.dc:description: Maximum up-score is recommended due to the convincing nature of the mouse model. Also, the variant is recurring across multiple apparently unrelated families.
Yang et al. study shows that this variant, when transgenically expressed in the mouse, generates a phenotype very similar to the human patient.

Authors report non-consanguinity for the patient. The authors propose the variant is acting in a dominant manner, but because only 3 genes were targeted for exome sequencing, presence of another mutation cannot be ruled out. No change to the default score was made.

evidence.rdfs:label: Kniazeva_1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: decreased visual acuity, bull’s-eye or similar macular atrophy, dark-choroid pattern, flavimaculatus flecks

evidence.dc:description: Only 2 segregations and therefore not included in final calculation.
evidence.rdfs:label: Michaelides2010_D
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Central scotomata, Right amblyopia, Bilateral macular atrophy and pigmentation, Bilateral BEM and optic nerve head drusen, Bilateral reduced macular AF corresponding to atrophy surrounded by high intensity AF rings, Bilateral perifoveal rings of increased AF surrounding mildly reduced foveal AF

evidence.rdfs:label: Martin-Gutierrez_1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: cone-rod dystrophy, mild maculopathy retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) changes, extensive macular and peripheral atrophy, peripheral pigmentation, bull’s eye maculopathy, attenuation of retinal vessels

evidence.rdfs:label: Kim_2017

member.rdfs:label: III:2
member.detectionMethod:
Targeted exome sequencing data were generated with three
million sequencing reads, covering 97.8% of targeted genes
with a sequencing coverage of ≥100X as well as 99.3% of ≥50X.
Targeted regions of PROM1 were fully covered, with a mean
depth ranging from 168X to 513X. A heterozygous missense
variant in PROM1 (NM_006017.1: c.1117C>T [p.R373C]) was
detected in the affected proband with a high read depth. Sanger
sequencing using newly-designed forward (5’-GGCTGGATGATGTTTATCAG-3’) and reverse primers (5’-GACTCTTGATGACCATATAATG-3’) confirmed the heterozygous presence of the
variant in the proband (Fig. 3). No pathogenic variants were
identified in the other 97 genes [known to be associated with inherited
retinal degenerations].

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Best corrected visual acuity was 0.6 in both eyes; fundus examination showed bilateral atrophic macular lesions with small flecks in the posterior pole; bull’s-eye pattern of hypo-autofluorescent macular lesions surrounded by hyper-autofluorescence; retinal pigment epithelium atrophy and photoreceptor layer defects. Clinical Electrophysiology of Vision standards showed slightly reduced amplitudes in both cone and rod responses.

evidence.rdfs:label: Michaelides2003_1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: bilateral macular retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) mottling and atrophy, perifoveal red granular patches, increased perifoveal autofluorescence bilaterally, Bull's eye maculopathy

evidence.rdfs:label: P5 and P6

member.rdfs:label: P5
member.detectionMethod: Targeted gene panel sequencing using next-generation sequencing (NGS) technique, confirmed by Sanger sequencing.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: decreased visual acuity, nyctalopia, degeneration at the macula, parafoveal degeneration, retinal degeneration in the macular area, wide-spread peripheral retinal degeneration

evidence.rdfs:label: P3 and P4

member.rdfs:label: P3
member.detectionMethod: Targeted gene panel sequencing using next-generation sequencing (NGS) technique; all variants identifed by NGS were confrmed by Sanger sequencing.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: degeneration at macula with a hyper-AF ring and parafoveal outer retinal degeneration

evidence.dc:description: Only 2 segregations reported, does not meet the required 4 segregations for final calculation.
evidence.rdfs:label: Michaelides2010_E

member.rdfs:label: EIII:1
member.detectionMethod: Families D and E were selected for directed screening for the R373C PROM1 variant on the basis of clinical phenotype. PCR-amplified products were screened for mutations by using denaturing high-performance liquid chromatography (DHPLC; WAVE system; Transgenomics, Crewe, UK). PCR fragments displaying DHPLC abnormal retention times were directly sequenced on both strands by using dye termination chemistry (BigDye Terminator ver. 3.1; ABI), in a final reaction volume of 10 L, and electrophoresed on a genetic analyzer (Prism 3100; ABI).

evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Bilateral BEM, optic nerve head drusen, Bilateral “bull’s eye’ lesions: ring of
decreased perifoveal AF, Speckled appearance, Bilateral central scotomata

evidence.dc:description: Targeted exome sequencing (TES) was analyzed using a genomic DNA (gDNA) sample of the proband (pedigree II:2) from the STGD4-like MD affected Chinese family.
evidence.rdfs:label: Imani_1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Bull’s eye maculopathy,  bilateral macular discoloration, and peripheral mottling with intraretinal pigment clumping, fundus flecks in both eyes, chorioretinal atrophy, perifoveal and parafoveal hypofluorescent

evidence.rdfs:label: Lee_1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Macular RPE mottling, Chorioretinal atrophy, Foveal sparing

evidence.dc:description: Whole-genome linkage analysis was performed that identified a disease interval containing PROM1. There were no other known or putative RP genes in the interval. Mutation screening of the entire coding sequence and intron–exon junctions of PROM1 was subsequently undertaken in the index case.
evidence.rdfs:label: Michaelides2010_C
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Subcapsular cataract, Night blindness, Macular atrophy, Peripheral pigment, abnormal ERG rod and cone response, Bull's eye maculopathy

Yang et al. study shows that this variant, when transgenically expressed in the mouse, generates a phenotype very similar to the human patient.

Yang et al. study shows that this variant, when transgenically expressed in the mouse, generates a phenotype very similar to the human patient.
Maximum up-score is recommended due to the convincing nature of the mouse model. Also, the variant is recurring across multiple apparently unrelated families.
Transgenic mouse model harboring this variant displays many similar retinal phenotypes observed in humans with same variant.

The transgenic mouse with PROM1 R373C mutation showed similar phenotypes observed in human STGD4 and MCDR2 cases associated with R373C mutation: fundus change, abnormal ERG recordings, progressive photoreceptor degeneration. Transgenic mouse expressing wild-type PROM1 did not show abnormalities, indicating phenotypes observed are associated with the R373C mutation and not due to overexpression of PROM1. In addition, the mutant mouse retina showed disorganized outer segment disc membranes and mislocalized PROM1 signal where expression was observed throughout the photoreceptor cell layers in contrast to control samples where PROM1 expression was restricted to the base of the outer segments, indicating that these cellular/molecular abnormalities may explain the phenotypes observed in human PROM1 R373C cases.
evidence.rdfs:label: Transgenic R373C mice have retinal abnormalities.

evidence.dc:description: One model of how PROM1 disruption causes cone rod retinal dystrophy is that PROM1 has a role in photoreceptor outer segment membrane homeostatsis. Here, authors propose that PROM1 accomplishes this by interacting with cholesterol, by bending membrane, and by promoting extracellular vesicle formation. This aligns with the disorganized outer segment membrane and PROM1 mislocalization observed in the photoreceptors of R373C mutant mouse (the predominant allele associated with autosomal dominant retinal phenotype).
evidence.rdfs:label: Prom1 transmembrane domain mutations impair EV formation

evidence.dc:description: Default scoring is recommended since the role of PROM1 within these subcellular structures is consistent with its known association with membrane protrusions in general (PMID: 10681530) and proposed function as an organizer of cell membrane topology in the morphogenesis of the developing photoreceptor cell outer segment disc membrane.
evidence.rdfs:label: PROM1 localizes to photoreceptor cell outer segment discs.

evidence.dc:description: One model of how PROM1 disruption causes cone rod retinal dystrophy is that PROM1 has a role in photoreceptor outer segment membrane homeostatsis. Here, authors propose that PROM1 accomplishes this by interacting with cholesterol, by bending membrane, and by promoting extracellular vesicle formation. This aligns with the disorganized outer segment membrane and PROM1 mislocalization observed in the photoreceptors of R373C mutant mouse (the predominant allele associated with autosomal dominant retinal phenotype).
evidence.rdfs:label: Prom1 mutations bind more tightly to cholesterol

evidence.dc:description: The co-immunoprecipitation data are consistent with the matching localizations of PROM1 and CDHR1 to the base of the photoreceptor outer segments within the mouse retina, and the role of variants in both genes in causing cone-rod dystrophy, macular dystrophy, and retinitis pigmentosa cases.
evidence.rdfs:label: PROM1 interacts with CDHR1.
